text:
James, a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ,
To the twelve tribes in the dispersion:
Greetings.
speaker: Narrator

text: My brothers and sisters, whenever you face various trials, consider it all joy,
speaker: Narrator

text: because you know that the testing of your faith produces endurance.
speaker: Narrator

text: And let endurance complete its work, so that you may be complete and whole, lacking in nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: If any of you is lacking in wisdom, ask God, who gives to all generously and ungrudgingly, and it will be given you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But ask in faith, never doubting, for the one who doubts is like a wave of the sea, driven and tossed by the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: ,For the doubter, being double-minded and unstable in every way, must not expect to receive anything from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let the brother or sister of humble means boast in having a high position
speaker: Narrator

text: and the rich in having been humbled, because the rich will disappear like a flower in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the sun rises with its scorching heat and withers the field; its flower falls, and its beauty perishes. It is the same way with the rich; in the midst of a busy life, they will wither away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Blessed is anyone who endures temptation. Such a one has stood the test and will receive the crown of life that the Lord has promised to those who love him.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one, when tempted, should say, “I am being tempted by God,” for God cannot be tempted by evil and he himself tempts no one.
speaker: Narrator

text: But one is tempted by one’s own desire, being lured and enticed by it;
speaker: Narrator

text: then, when desire has conceived, it engenders sin, and sin, when it is fully grown, gives birth to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be deceived, my beloved brothers and sisters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every generous act of giving, with every perfect gift, is from above, coming down from the Father of lights, with whom there is no variation or shadow due to change.
speaker: Narrator

text: In fulfillment of his own purpose he gave birth to us by the word of truth, so that we would become a kind of first fruits of his creatures.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must understand this, my beloved brothers and sisters: let everyone be quick to listen, slow to speak, slow to anger,
speaker: Narrator

text: for human anger does not produce God’s righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore rid yourselves of all sordidness and rank growth of wickedness, and welcome with meekness the implanted word that has the power to save your souls.
speaker: Narrator

text: But be doers of the word and not merely hearers who deceive themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if any are hearers of the word and not doers, they are like those who look at themselves in a mirror;
speaker: Narrator

text: for they look at themselves and, on going away, immediately forget what they were like.
speaker: Narrator

text: But those who look into the perfect law, the law of liberty, and persevere, being not hearers who forget but doers who act—they will be blessed in their doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: If any think they are religious and do not bridle their tongues but deceive their hearts, their religion is worthless.
speaker: Narrator

text: Religion that is pure and undefiled before God the Father is this: to care for orphans and widows in their distress and to keep oneself unstained by the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: My brothers and sisters, do not claim the faith of our Lord Jesus Christ of glory while showing partiality.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if a person with gold rings and in fine clothes comes into your assembly, and if a poor person in dirty clothes also comes in,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if you take notice of the one wearing the fine clothes and say, “Have a seat here in a good place, please,” while to the one who is poor you say, “Stand there,” or, “Sit by my footstool,”
speaker: Narrator

text: have you not made distinctions among yourselves and become judges with evil thoughts?
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen, my beloved brothers and sisters. Has not God chosen the poor in the world to be rich in faith and to be heirs of the kingdom that he has promised to those who love him?
speaker: Narrator

text: But you have dishonored the poor person. Is it not the rich who oppress you? Is it not they who drag you into the courts?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is it not they who blaspheme the excellent name that was invoked over you?
speaker: Narrator

text: If you really fulfill the royal law according to the scripture, “You shall love your neighbor as yourself,” you do well.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you show partiality, you commit sin and are convicted by the law as transgressors.
speaker: Narrator

text: For whoever keeps the whole law but fails in one point has become accountable for all of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the one who said, “You shall not commit adultery,” also said, “You shall not murder.” Now if you do not commit adultery but you murder, you have become a transgressor of the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: So speak and so act as those who are to be judged by the law of liberty.
speaker: Narrator

text: For judgment will be without mercy to anyone who has shown no mercy; mercy triumphs over judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: What good is it, my brothers and sisters, if someone claims to have faith but does not have works? Surely that faith cannot save, can it?
speaker: Narrator

text: If a brother or sister is naked and lacks daily food
speaker: Narrator

text: and one of you says to them, “Go in peace; keep warm and eat your fill,” and yet you do not supply their bodily needs, what is the good of that?
speaker: Narrator

text: So faith by itself, if it has no works, is dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: But someone will say, “You have faith, and I have works.” Show me your faith apart from works, and I by my works will show you faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: You believe that God is one; you do well. Even the demons believe—and shudder.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you want to be shown, you senseless person, that faith apart from works is worthless?
speaker: Narrator

text: Was not our ancestor Abraham justified by works when he offered his son Isaac on the altar?
speaker: Narrator

text: You see that faith was active along with his works, and by works faith was brought to completion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus the scripture was fulfilled that says, “Abraham believed God, and it was reckoned to him as righteousness,” and he was called the friend of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You see that a person is justified by works and not by faith alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Likewise, was not Rahab the prostitute also justified by works when she welcomed the messengers and sent them out by another road?
speaker: Narrator

text: For just as the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without works is also dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not many of you should become teachers, my brothers and sisters, for you know that we who teach will face stricter judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all of us make many mistakes. Anyone who makes no mistakes in speaking is mature, able to keep the whole body in check with a bridle.
speaker: Narrator

text: If we put bits into the mouths of horses to make them obey us, we guide their whole bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or look at ships: though they are so large and are driven by strong winds, yet they are guided by a very small rudder wherever the will of the pilot directs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So also the tongue is a small member, yet it boasts of great exploits.
How great a forest is set ablaze by a such a small fire!
speaker: Narrator

text: And the tongue is a fire. The tongue is placed among our members as a world of iniquity; it stains the whole body, sets on fire the cycle of life, and is itself set on fire by hell.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every species of beast and bird, of reptile and sea creature, can be tamed and has been tamed by the human species,
speaker: Narrator

text: but no one can tame the tongue—a restless evil, full of deadly poison.
speaker: Narrator

text: With it we bless the Lord and Father, and with it we curse people, made in the likeness of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the same mouth comes a blessing and a curse. My brothers and sisters, this ought not to be so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Does a spring pour forth from the same opening both fresh and brackish water?
speaker: Narrator

text: Can a fig tree, my brothers and sisters, yield olives or a grapevine figs? No more can salt water yield fresh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is wise and knowledgeable among you? Show by your good life that your works are done with gentleness born of wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you have bitter envy and selfish ambition in your hearts, do not be arrogant and lie about the truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is not wisdom that comes down from above but is earthly, unspiritual, devilish.
speaker: Narrator

text: For where there is envy and selfish ambition, there will also be disorder and wickedness of every kind.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the wisdom from above is first pure, then peaceable, gentle, willing to yield, full of mercy and good fruits, without a trace of partiality or hypocrisy.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the fruit of righteousness is sown in peace by those who make peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those conflicts and disputes among you, where do they come from? Do they not come from your cravings that are at war within you?
speaker: Narrator

text: You want something and do not have it, so you commit murder. And you covet something and cannot obtain it, so you engage in disputes and conflicts. You do not have because you do not ask.
speaker: Narrator

text: You ask and do not receive because you ask wrongly, in order to spend what you get on your pleasures.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adulterers! Do you not know that friendship with the world is enmity with God? Therefore whoever wishes to be a friend of the world becomes an enemy of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or do you suppose that the scripture speaks to no purpose? Does the spirit that God caused to dwell in us desire envy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
But God gives all the more grace; therefore it says,
“God opposes the proud
    but gives grace to the humble.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Submit yourselves therefore to God. Resist the devil, and he will flee from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Draw near to God, and he will draw near to you. Cleanse your hands, you sinners, and purify your hearts, you double-minded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lament and mourn and weep. Let your laughter be turned into mourning and your joy into dejection.
speaker: Narrator

text: Humble yourselves before the Lord, and he will exalt you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not speak evil against one another, brothers and sisters. Whoever speaks evil against another or judges another speaks evil against the law and judges the law, but if you judge the law, you are not a doer of the law but a judge.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is one lawgiver and judge who is able to save and to destroy. So who, then, are you to judge your neighbor?
speaker: Narrator

text: Come now, you who say, “Today or tomorrow we will go to such and such a town and spend a year there, doing business and making money.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet you do not even know what tomorrow will bring. What is your life? For you are a mist that appears for a little while and then vanishes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead you ought to say, “If the Lord wishes, we will live and do this or that.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As it is, you boast in your arrogance; all such boasting is evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone, then, who knows the right thing to do and fails to do it commits sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come now, you rich people, weep and wail for the miseries that are coming to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your riches have rotted, and your clothes are moth-eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your gold and silver have rusted, and their rust will be evidence against you, and it will eat your flesh like fire. You have laid up treasure during the last days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen! The wages of the laborers who mowed your fields, which you kept back by fraud, cry out, and the cries of the harvesters have reached the ears of the Lord of hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have lived on the earth in luxury and in pleasure; you have nourished your hearts in a day of slaughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have condemned and murdered the righteous one, who does not resist you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be patient, therefore, brothers and sisters, until the coming of the Lord. The farmer waits for the precious crop from the earth, being patient with it until it receives the early and the late rains.
speaker: Narrator

text: You also must be patient. Strengthen your hearts, for the coming of the Lord is near.
speaker: Narrator

text: Brothers and sisters, do not grumble against one another, so that you may not be judged. See, the Judge is standing at the doors!
speaker: Narrator

text: As an example of suffering and patience, brothers and sisters, take the prophets who spoke in the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, we call blessed those who showed endurance. You have heard of the endurance of Job, and you have seen the outcome that the Lord brought about, for the Lord is compassionate and merciful.
speaker: Narrator

text: Above all, brothers and sisters, do not swear, either by heaven or by earth or by any other oath, but let your “Yes” be yes and your “No” be no, so that you may not fall under condemnation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Are any among you suffering? They should pray. Are any cheerful? They should sing songs of praise.
speaker: Narrator

text: Are any among you sick? They should call for the elders of the church and have them pray over them, anointing them with oil in the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prayer of faith will save the sick, and the Lord will raise them up, and anyone who has committed sins will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore confess your sins to one another and pray for one another, so that you may be healed. The prayer of the righteous is powerful and effective.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah was a human like us, and he prayed fervently that it might not rain, and for three years and six months it did not rain on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he prayed again, and the heaven gave rain, and the earth yielded its harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text: My brothers and sisters, if anyone among you wanders from the truth and is brought back by another,
speaker: Narrator

text: you should know that whoever brings back a sinner from wandering will save the sinner’s soul from death and will cover a multitude of sins.
speaker: Narrator
